name: Mesopotamia
info: Often called the Cradle of Civilization, Mesopotamia was located between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. It is known for developing cuneiform, the first writing system. Major civilizations here included the Sumerians, Akkadians, Babylonians, and Assyrians. Mesopotamians also had laws. The Code of Hammurabi was a collection of laws inscribed on a stone. The Code of Hammurabi is where the term an eye for an eye came from.

name: Ancient Egypt
info: Ancient Egypt thrived along the Nile River. Egypt is famous for its monumental pyramids and the Sphinx. The rules of Ancient Egypt were called Pharaohs. Many Pharaohs were buried in the Valley of the Kings. One of the most well-known tombs in the Valley of the Kings is the tomb of King Tut. It was almost fully intact when found.

name: Indus Valley Civilization
info: In present-day Pakistan and northwest India, the Indus Valley was one of the world's earliest urban centers. Known for its well-planned cities, this civilization had advanced sanitation and standardized brick construction. They had a standardized system of weights and measures. The Indus writing remains undeciphered, and their decline remains a mystery. It's possibly due to environmental factors or invasions.

name: Ancient China (Xia Dynasty)
info: The Xia Dynasty is considered China's first historical dynasty. According to lengend it was founded by Yu the Great, who controlled the Great Flood and establishing a system of canals and irrigation. It laid the foundation for future Chinese dynasties, with the establishment of a hereditary monarchy. The Xia is believed to have contributed to the development of metallurgy, agriculture, and the beginnings of Chinese writing.

name: Minoan Civilization
info: The Minoans flourished on the island of Crete. Known for their advanced palaces, particularly the one at Knossos, they had a vibrant culture, advanced art, and trade networks across the Mediterranean. They developed a unique script called Linear A, which remains undeciphered
